title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires mandatory drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations such as Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association, the National Football League, and others as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates professional sports associations to conduct random drug testing on athletes at least once a year for performance-enhancing substances as determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and the Secretary. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires random drug testing for performance-enhancing substances determined by the Secretary. Tests must be conducted by an independent party, and penalties for a positive test include suspension from participation in the professional sports association for a minimum of 2 years, with permanent suspension for repeat offenders. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing for performance-enhancing substances with penalties including suspension from the professional sports association for a minimum of 2 years. Athletes with positive test results must have their names disclosed to the public and are entitled to an appeals process within 5 days of learning about the test. The association must hold a hearing and reach a final decision within 30 days, with penalties stayed pending the appeal process. SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS.

The Secretary may exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from mandatory testing.

SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules are issued, fines up to $5,000,000 can be imposed on associations not complying with testing regulations.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress. A study on college and secondary school athlete drug testing policies will be conducted by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General will report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment on the effectiveness of drug testing policies for college and secondary school athletes, including recommendations for expanding regulations to athletic associations.
